title.value: Essential surgery delivery in the Northern Kivu Province of the Democratic Republic of the Congo
title.justification: The title of the paper is directly mentioned at the beginning of the document.
title.quote: Essential surgery delivery in the Northern Kivu Province of the Democratic Republic of the Congo

extractions.description: The study evaluates the surgical capacity in Northern Kivu, DRC, assessing factors like workforce, infrastructure, and equipment, and compares them against international benchmarks.

type.justification: The study is empirical as it involves data collection and analysis of the surgical capacity in the Northern Kivu province of the DRC.
type.quote: Methods Hospitals were assessed in the North Kivu province of the DRC. Hospital characteristics and surgical rates were determined using the WHO-PGSSC hospital assessment tool and operating room (OR) registries.

name.justification: The primary focus of the paper is on assessing surgical delivery and healthcare capacity in a specific region.
name.quote: The study assessed the relationship between the number of Bellwether surgeries, the surgical capacity, human capital, and perioperative services in two Congolese health zones in 2021.

name.justification: The paper addresses global health issues, specifically surgical care accessibility in low-income countries.
name.quote: The Lancet Commission on Global Surgery (LCoGS) indicators of surgical capacity such as perioperative workforce and surgical volume are unknown in many low- and middle-income countries (LMICs) including the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC).

name.justification: The paper discusses the economic aspects of surgical care, including costs and health insurance coverage.
name.quote: The procedural costs were not significantly different between the public and non-public sectors. Of note, none of the patients accessing surgical care in public hospitals had health insurance, which meant that they paid fully out of pocket (OOP).
